author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Jonathan Weisman
title: In Ohio Senate Fight, G.O.P. Shows Strains of Its Identity Crisis
description: Republicans agree that values they view as traditional are at risk, but they’re wrestling with whether isolationism is the answer to their misgivings about global interconnectedness.
content: CLEVELAND — The homestretch of Ohio’s contentious Republican Senate primary has revealed a party united in its conviction that American values, indeed the nation’s way of life, are under attack, but divided on whether to embrace a strict isolationism to address its mounting misgivings about global interconnectedness and American leadership abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cade Metz
title: Another Firing Among Google’s A.I. Brain Trust, and More Discord
description: The researchers are considered a key to the company’s future. But they have had a hard time shaking infighting and controversy over a variety of issues.
content: Less than two years after Google dismissed two researchers who criticized the biases built into artificial intelligence systems, the company has fired a researcher who questioned a paper it published on the abilities of a specialized type of artificial intelligence used in making computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Spiel of Fortune
description: Netflix introduces a post-truth game show, for an era when seeming right sometimes trumps being right.
content: There are plenty of things on Netflix’s new quiz show that you’ve seen on game shows before. For starters, there’s Howie Mandel. There’s a big board of increasing cash prizes. There are contestants answering multiple-choice questions about science, history and geography. Sometimes — often, actually — they answer wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Eisen and Donald Ayer
title: Will Trump Face a Legal Reckoning in Georgia?
description: It may be the most serious prospect of prosecution that Trump and his associates are facing.
content: Over 2,300 text messages to and from Mark Meadows, a former chief of staff for Donald J. Trump, offer stunning real-time details of the efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election. Not least among the revelations are Mr. Meadows’s repeated overtures to the Georgia secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, with Mr. Meadows pressing the Georgian to be in communication with the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: What My Mother’s Cooking Taught Me
description: She was a midcentury housewife with an innovative style and a taste for fine ingredients. That care in the kitchen shaped my approach as a food writer and home cook.
content: Whenever I slice and sauté onions, I think of my mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Vitello
title: Ron Galella, Celebrity-Hounding Photographer, Dies at 91
description: He personified the paparazzi — brazen and relentless in chasing the famous, particularly Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. But his pictures also came to be admired.
content: Ron Galella, the freelance photographer who relentlessly pursued Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis until a judge barred him from taking her picture, who pestered Marlon Brando until Brando broke his jaw, and who for better or worse helped define today’s boundary-challenged culture of celebrity, died on Saturday at his home in Montville, N.J. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Is This the Summer We’ve Been Waiting For?
description: Tell us what the summer of 2022 means to you, and how you’re approaching it.
content: Last summer felt full of promise. Many of us entered the season freshly jabbed, and after months spent languishing in lockdown were ready to take back our social lives. During those first few weeks of warmer weather, many of us took our first steps toward re-engaging with friends, events, colleagues and a brighter future — until the Delta variant crashed the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: After a Two-Year Dip, Evictions Accelerate in New York
description: Activity in the city’s housing courts, which used to process more eviction cases than any other city in the nation, is rising after a pandemic moratorium.
content: In New York, where landlords typically move to evict more people than in any other city in the nation, the housing courts sat in an unusual stupor for some two years. But as pandemic restrictions ease, they are beginning to hum anew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohsin Hamid
title: In a Sick World, Choosing Between Freedom and Restriction
description: Ali Smith’s new novel, “Companion Piece,” is set in a pandemic-ravaged, post-Brexit Britain, with a perplexing choice at its center.
content: In a pandemic-ravaged and post-Brexit Britain, our narrator, Sandy Gray, who is anything but gray, character-wise, though in her present state of personal and political despondency she might well feel she is, receives an unexpected call from one Martina Pelf, formerly Martina Inglis, a university acquaintance who has recently been held for seven and a half hours at border control, an officer annoyed by her dual citizenship (“Is one country not enough for you?”), and Martina is calling to share this with Sandy, and to ask Sandy a question — and so begins Ali Smith’s 18th book, the superb novel “Companion Piece.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Should We Abandon Email?
description: Do you think young people are leading a movement away from email? Is that a good thing?
content: How do you feel about email?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Beijing’s Fight against Lockdowns
description: And Mariupol evacuees start to emerge.
content: Beijing reopened the Xiaotangshan hospital, which has more than 1,000 beds, after recording a few hundred cases in recent weeks. On Monday, officials announced 50 new cases in the city of 22 million, down from the 59 reported on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pandemic Home Market Creates Vast Riches, and More Inequality
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 2, 2022.
content: “It’s not that they’re not doing anything; it’s that they’ve aggressively blocked development in so many places.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Boston in Case on Christian Flag
description: The court unanimously ruled that the city, which has approved many other requests to raise flags at its City Hall, violated a Christian group’s free speech rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Monday that the City of Boston had violated the First Amendment when it refused to let a private group raise a Christian flag in front of its City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Wendell Pierce to Star in ‘Death of a Salesman’ on Broadway
description: The production, also starring Sharon D Clarke and featuring André De Shields, will arrive some time next season.
content: Wendell Pierce is ready for another run as Willy Loman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Plant-Based Chocolate Bar Will Remind You of the Sea
description: The chocolate company Tcho and Monterey Bay Aquarium teamed up to create a dark chocolate bar with sea salt and seaweed.
content: Tcho, a chocolate company based in Berkeley, Calif., has collaborated with the Monterey Bay Aquarium to create a new bar: Deep, Dark and Salty, incorporating sea salt and seaweed for a slightly crunchy, saline profile to complement the fruitiness of the dark chocolate. Tcho’s chocolate maker, Brad Kintzer, and the aquarium’s executive chef, Matthew Beaudin, designed the bar for the exhibit “Into the Deep.” The bar, made with sea lettuce from Monterey Bay Seaweeds and salt from Big Sur Salt, is vegan. Ten percent of the price benefits the aquarium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: In Bid to Boost Peacock, Universal Will Send 3 Movies Straight to Streaming
description: The move is not only an attempt to attract subscribers but an acknowledgment that releasing some films theatrically has become more of a gamble.
content: Donna Langley, the head of Universal’s Motion Picture Entertainment Group, stepped on the stage at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas last week and reaffirmed her commitment to movie theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Learning More
description: Why did U.S. schools make so much progress in the 1990s and early 2000s?
content: Readers of this newsletter know that we try to avoid bad-news bias. My colleagues and I cover plenty of worrisome stories here, but we also want to make sure we’re covering encouraging ones. The world is full of both, after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: A Billionaire Hedge Fund Manager Predicts the Future — and What He Sees Is Concerning
description: Ray Dalio discusses the economic and political mechanics of a changing world order.
content: The Russia-Ukraine war has opened up questions about America’s role in global affairs and how the balance of power will reshuffle. These questions aren’t new; the discussion of the end of American dominance and the rise of new powers like China has captivated political and economic discourse. It is also the subject of Ray Dalio’s latest book, “Principles for Dealing With the Changing World Order.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What American Mothers Really Need
description: If red-state legislators truly want to limit abortions — legal and illegal — they must create conditions that give women a genuine choice.
content: NASHVILLE — I’ve been watching anti-abortion bills sweep the red states this season, and it occurs to me that the week of Mother’s Day might be a good time for a red-state mother like me to weigh in. I fervently support a woman’s right to choose, but I still spend a lot of time thinking about how Republican legislators could achieve their real goal without also trying to undo settled legal precedent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert E. Rubin and Jacob J. Lew
title: A Plan to Help Kids Without Increasing Inflation
description: Lawmakers should make the Child Tax Credit available to families with low or no earnings. There’s a way to do this without adding to inflation.
content: We both served as secretary of the Treasury, and we have been associated with economic policies that are both fiscally responsible and invest in our future. It is our strong view that Congress should act this year to ease the financial strain on low-income families raising children, and that these policies should be paid for in a package that reduces the deficit. This is not just morally right, but a critical investment in our nation’s economic future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia and Dina Litovsky
title: In photos: The People’s Ball in Brooklyn.
description: The Brooklyn Public Library celebrated its 125th birthday on Sunday by bringing back the People’s Ball. Unlike the Met Gala — an exclusive, invitation-only event, where tickets start at $35,000 — this gala was held in the People’s Republic of Brooklyn, and attendance was democratized. All New Yorkers were welcomed as guests to celebrate their unique style, fashion and energy at the Central Library at Grand Army Plaza.
content: The Brooklyn Public Library celebrated its 125th birthday on Sunday by bringing back the People’s Ball. Unlike the Met Gala — an exclusive, invitation-only event, where tickets start at $35,000 — this gala was held in the People’s Republic of Brooklyn, and attendance was democratized. All New Yorkers were welcomed as guests to celebrate their unique style, fashion and energy at the Central Library at Grand Army Plaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Tennessee Halts Executions After Failing to Test Lethal Injection Drugs
description: Five men scheduled for execution this year were granted temporary reprieves while the state investigates why the drugs had not been tested for toxins.
content: Tennessee’s governor on Monday ordered a halt to all executions through the end of the year and opened an investigation into why the state had failed to properly test lethal injection drugs that were set to be used on a prisoner last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What’s New York Fashion Really About?
description: On the eve of the Met Gala, Thom Browne has an idea.
content: The existential questions of American fashion — what is it? can it be defined? how does it relate to shifting American identity? — were thrust into the cultural conversation in September with the Metropolitan Museum’s fall Costume Institute show, a revisionist look at the “lexicon” of design born in this country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: He Spurred a Revolution in Psychiatry. Then He ‘Disappeared.’
description: In 1972, Dr. John Fryer risked his career to tell his colleagues that gay people were not mentally ill. His act sent ripples through the legal, medical and justice systems.
content: On the second day of the annual convention of the American Psychiatric Association in 1972, something extraordinary happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Cioppino This Good Can’t Be a Cliché
description: In San Francisco, the hallmark seafood stew can be — and often is — a tired menu item, but our critic finds that the right version still thrills.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Roseann Grimm was growing up, there was always a pot of long-simmered red sauce on the stove. Her grandfather Nicola DeSimone, a fisherman from Amalfi, Italy, used it to start a pan of cioppino, a seafood stew made with crab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: As Feinstein Declines, Democrats Struggle to Manage an Open Secret
description: Democrats have quietly accepted the California senator’s memory issues as the status quo, even as her inner circle frets that the spectacle of her difficulties on the job could tarnish her legacy.
content: WASHINGTON — She was once pressed to run for governor of California by President Bill Clinton. She was considered as a running mate to former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. And after the bitter 2008 Democratic primary, it was in her living room that former Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton met to make peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: In Epicurean Hong Kong, a Humble $4 Lunchbox Is Now All the Rage
description: In a city pummeled by political upheaval, economic downturn and the pandemic, bare-bones ‘two dishes and rice’ restaurants have become a go-to destination across all social classes.
content: HONG KONG — The lines begin forming before lunchtime and wind on well into the night, with customers outside craning their necks for views of the day’s selection through the window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fairbank
title: How to Avoid (and Fix) a Bum Ankle
description: Ankle instability is often the result of nerve and ligament damage. These exercises can help get you back on, and stay on, your feet.
content: When Chris Peterson sprained his ankle playing football in high school, he brushed it off as a minor injury. His ankle hurt for a couple days, but no one suggested he see a doctor, and soon enough, it felt better. “I got back to playing as soon as I could,” said Dr. Peterson, now a physical therapist at Washington University in St. Louis. However, although his ankle didn’t hurt, it just wasn’t the same afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty and Danya Issawi
title: What Is a ‘Nepotism Baby’?
description: Gen Zers have turned a term of derision into one of admiration. That doesn’t mean they’re not jealous, though.
content: Meriem Derradji couldn’t help but feel a twinge of betrayal when she discovered that one of her favorite actresses on “Euphoria” was not the self-made up-and-comer she thought her to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Diana Nguyen, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rob Szypko, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: Are Unions Making a Comeback?
description: What the explosion of union membership during the 1930s can tell us about today’s revival.
content: The United States is seeing a revival in union membership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez endorses Nina Turner in a rematch for an Ohio House seat.
description: Ms. Turner is challenging Representative Shontel Brown for a second time in Tuesday’s primary election, after Ms. Brown won a special election last year.
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, one of the nation’s most prominent left-wing officials, endorsed Nina Turner’s congressional bid in the final hours of a divisive Ohio contest that has increasingly attracted national Democratic attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: South Africa’s latest surge is a possible preview of the pandemic’s next chapter.
description: The spread of two newly discovered subvariants has doctors watching closely.
content: Coronavirus cases are surging again in South Africa, and public health experts are monitoring the situation, eager to know what’s driving the spike, what it says about immunity from previous infections and what its implications are globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: New Subvariants in South Africa
description: A surge in the country is being driven by BA.4 and BA.5.
content: South Africa is seeing signs of a fifth wave of the coronavirus as cases once again surge across the country. The recent spike is linked to two new subvariants that are part of the Omicron family: BA.4 and BA.5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Sameer Yasir
title: Bangladesh Shutters Dozens of Schools Set Up by Rohingya in Camps
description: More than 30 schools, teaching tens of thousands of Rohingya students, were closed in Bangladesh, where officials are said to have feared the schools would encourage the refugees to stay permanently.
content: KUTUPALONG CAMP, Bangladesh — Every morning, Mohammad Reyaz, a sixth grader, appears in uniform outside his school for Rohingya refugees in the Cox’s Bazar area of Bangladesh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: How the Rangers Got Back to the N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Four years ago, the Rangers’ front office asked fans to be patient while it rebuilt the roster. The wait is over: New York will face the Pittsburgh Penguins in the first round.
content: Mark Reiss has been a Rangers season-ticket holder since 2001, perched high in the blue seats with his two sons, who grew from toddlers to adults under the iconic Madison Square Garden ceiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Alex Traub
title: Arrest Warrant Is Issued for Jail Officer Who Disappeared With Inmate
description: The authorities in Alabama were searching for a veteran corrections officer who vanished with a murder suspect after saying she was taking him to a courthouse appointment.
content: The authorities in Alabama said on Monday that they had issued an arrest warrant for a corrections officer who disappeared with a murder suspect after they left a jail together last week for an appointment that turned out not to exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Daniel Berehulak
title: They Fell Deeply in Love in Bucha. One Russian Bullet Ended It All.
description: Over nearly two decades, Iryna Abramova and her husband, Oleh, built a life of love and happiness. Now, she says, she wishes the Russian soldiers had shot her, too.
content: BUCHA, Ukraine — She called him Sunshine. He called her Kitty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Brian Benjamin Won’t Be on the New York Ballot After All
description: Lawmakers have passed legislation that would allow individuals who have been arrested or indicted to be removed from state ballots.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Brian A. Benjamin, the former New York lieutenant governor who resigned after being indicted on federal bribery charges, will no longer appear on the state Democratic primary ballot after legislation passed on Monday made it possible to remove him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Met Gala Is Bound to Be Gilded and Over-the-Top
description: The annual fashion extravaganza happens tonight, with tickets priced at $35,000 and invitations required.
content: Good morning. We’ll get expert guidance on what to expect at the Met Gala tonight, and we’ll preview a new advertising campaign intended to scare drivers into slowing down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kauffman
title: Growing a New Future for Farming
description: By restoring soil health, Donald Wyse hopes to transform farms, to the benefit of farmers and their customers.
content: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: 5 Things to Know About Casinos That May Be Headed for the N.Y.C. Area
description: Yonkers, Queens and maybe Manhattan: The sites for three new casinos have not yet been set in stone.
content: Whether New Yorkers are ready or not, casinos will soon be coming to the New York City area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Sisters Recount Perilous Escape From Mariupol as Russians Closed In
description: The women say they were forced onto a bus to Russian-controlled territory, then escaped what Ukrainian and U.S. officials have described as “filtration” centers for a system of forced expulsions to Russia.
content: Vera and Nicole thought they had endured the worst of the war as Russia besieged their city, Mariupol, for weeks. The sisters helped neighbors bury neighbors, melted snow for drinking water and survived a bombardment that tore a hole in the ceiling of their home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Court and the Culture Wars
description: When “religious freedom” gets complicated.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: National Democrats Make Last-Gasp Push to Keep N.Y. District Maps
description: Democrats are seeking to reinstate congressional district maps that were declared unconstitutional last week by New York’s highest court.
content: With the balance of the House of Representatives at stake, national Democrats made an 11th-hour appeal to a federal court on Monday to intervene in New York’s heated redistricting dispute, hoping to reinstate House maps thrown out by the state’s highest court last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Jan. 6 Panel Seeks Interviews With Three More G.O.P. Lawmakers
description: All three quickly declined. The panel also said it had evidence that some House Republicans sought pardons from President Donald J. Trump in connection with the effort to overturn the election.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol sent letters on Monday seeking interviews with three Republican members of Congress, and the panel said it had gathered evidence that some House Republicans sought presidential pardons in the aftermath of the violence that engulfed the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Why the Debate Over Russian Uranium Worries U.S. Tribal Nations
description: If imports end because of the war, American companies may look to increase domestic mining, which has a toxic history on Indigenous lands.
content: KAIBAB NATIONAL FOREST, Ariz. — After Russia invaded Ukraine in February, the United States slapped bans on Russian energy sources from oil to coal. But one critical Russian energy import was left alone: uranium, which the United States relies on to fuel more than 90 nuclear reactors around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: Ukrainian civilians flee Mariupol
description: It was the first large-scale evacuation from the last bastion of Ukrainian resistance in the city.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Pusha T Earns First No. 1 Album With ‘It’s Almost Dry’
description: The rapper, 44, tops the Billboard chart this week, more than 20 years into a workmanlike career.
content: More than 20 years into a workmanlike rap career, Pusha T has landed his first No. 1 album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Wilke
title: An Anaconda’s Play Date With Dolphins Took a Strange Turn
description: Why were Bolivian river dolphins swimming around with a large predatory snake in their mouths? “There are so many questions,” one researcher said.
content: In August 2021, a research team was documenting biodiversity near the Tijamuchi River in Bolivia when they saw some animals that are typically difficult to observe: Bolivian river dolphins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Sharrett
title: Chasing a Mighty Relic of Yesteryear: Union Pacific 4014
description: A train enthusiast reflects on the grandeur of the world’s largest operating steam locomotive, recently returned to service.
content: I stood beside the railroad tracks in the heat of the Texas summer, listening intently for the distinctive sound of a steam locomotive. Other than the cicadas chirping from the nearby mesquite trees, I couldn’t register anything out of the ordinary. I closed my eyes to heighten my sense of hearing — still nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: NBC News says parts of 11 articles were plagiarized.
description: An editor’s note has been placed on each article and the plagiarized sections have been removed.
content: NBC News said on Monday that it had found instances of plagiarism in 11 articles written by a reporter over the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Democrats’ Mystery: How to Brighten a Presidency and a National Mood
description: Crucial left-leaning voters have soured on President Biden, and Americans of all stripes are angry. Democratic leaders can’t agree on what to tell them.
content: LAKEWOOD, Ohio — At a Whole Foods in one moderate Cleveland suburb, shoppers recently worried about war, inflation, a “scary” political climate — and a Democratic Party some saw as slow to address the nation’s burning problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $5 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Santa Monica, a 1925 Tudor Revival home in Ojai and a Craftsman-inspired bungalow in Los Gatos.
content: This house, on a hillside above Santa Monica Canyon, was designed by Kevin A. Clark, an architect whose work incorporates elements of the Spanish- and Mediterranean-style architecture built in Southern California in the 1920s and 1930s. It was featured in “The Spanish Style House: From Enchanted Andalusia to the California Dream,” published by Rizzoli in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In Kyiv, residents cautiously return and embrace a renewed sense of normalcy.
description: A month after the Ukrainian Army defeated the Russian forces that had partly encircled Ukraine’s capital, tension is slowly seeping out of the city.
content: It had been a sound missing from Ukraine’s capital for months. Then, on a balmy spring afternoon, the chatter of children’s voices again filled a playground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Apple faces E.U. antitrust charges over Apple Pay.
description: Regulators said Apple had blocked PayPal and others from access to technology in the iPhone that lets people make a purchase with a quick tap.
content: European Union regulators said on Monday that Apple had broken antitrust laws by unfairly undercutting companies whose payment services competed with Apple Pay, in the latest crackdown by European authorities on the world’s largest tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: As World Cup Nears, Brands Weigh Cost of Teaming With Qatar
description: Troubled by worker abuse and human rights, some World Cup sponsors are distancing themselves from the host nation. But not everyone is backing away.
content: For Gary Lineker, a starring role in Qatar’s big show was not an option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Try Harder!’ and ‘Sheryl’
description: A documentary about college admissions airs on PBS, and Sheryl Crow tells her story in a new Showtime documentary.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 2-8. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Russia Is Barred From Women’s Euros and 2023 World Cup
description: Russian soccer teams and clubs were barred from all European competitions, including the Champions League, for the 2022-23 season.
content: Russia was ejected from this summer’s European women’s soccer championship and barred from qualifying for the 2023 Women’s World Cup on Monday, deepening a sporting isolation that resulted from the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Catch and Release: Rocket Lab Grabs Booster Falling From Space With a Helicopter
description: The company aims to join Elon Musk’s SpaceX in reusing rocket boosters, which can lower costs and increase the frequency of launching to orbit.
content: Catch a falling rocket and bring it back to shore …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Can California Build Its Way Out of the Homelessness Crisis?
description: The case for keeping people from losing their homes in the first place.
content: The homelessness problem in California is often presented as a simple math equation. If we have x number of people in the state and the number of housing units is lower than x, we will have people who are homeless. The solution to a supply problem, in other words, is more supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Pilots Contend With Record Number of Laser Strikes, F.A.A. Says
description: When a laser pointer reaches a cockpit, it can disorient or “completely incapacitate” a pilot, said the agency, which recorded more than 9,700 such cases last year.
content: One foggy night in December 2018, David Hill was trying to land a helicopter when a beam of light suddenly overwhelmed his night vision goggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The History of Japanese Green Tea in America
description: The Culinary Historians of New York will hold a talk with the writer Robert Hellyer on the drink’s popularity in the 19th century.
content: If you think the enjoyment of green tea is a relatively new pursuit in the United States, a Zoom talk for the Culinary Historians of New York will set you straight. Robert Hellyer, an associate professor of history at Wake Forest University and the author of “Green Tea With Milk and Sugar: When Japan Filled America’s Tea Cups,” will explain how Japanese green tea became popular in 19th century America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The W.N.B.A. Strikes an Uneasy Silence Over Brittney Griner
description: Advisers are taking a discreet approach to negotiating the Phoenix Mercury center’s release from Russian detention, putting her anguished teammates and the league in a discomfiting position.
content: PHOENIX — When will Brittney Griner be set free?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Former Philadelphia Officer Faces Murder Charge in Boy’s Shooting
description: Edsaul Mendoza, who was fired last month, has been arrested in connection with the shooting death of Thomas Siderio, 12, the authorities said.
content: A Philadelphia police officer who was fired after he fatally shot a 12-year-old boy in the back in March has been charged with murder in connection with the shooting, the authorities said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Tacky’ Finds the Joy in Bad Taste
description: Rax King can allude to Updike and Odysseus, but in these essays she is far more concerned with Creed, Snooki and the Cheesecake Factory.
content: Chuck Klosterman, in his book “The Nineties,” argues that that decade was the last one to really feel like a decade, with its own immutable values and fashions and ideas. We’ve seemed to live since, he has said, “in a period of perpetual now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise, Noam Scheiber and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Amazon Union Loses Vote at Second Staten Island Warehouse
description: The results were a setback for the upstart Amazon Labor Union, which won a landmark victory last month at a larger Amazon warehouse nearby.
content: The growing labor organizing efforts at Amazon were dealt a blow on Monday when workers voted by a wide margin to reject joining a union at a warehouse on Staten Island, just weeks after the union won a landmark victory at a larger facility nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Pelosi says Russia’s war merits the ‘strongest possible’ response.
description: Following a visit to Kyiv over the weekend, Speaker Nancy Pelosi held talks in Poland with President Andrzej Duda, a meeting aimed at deepening Washington’s partnership with a key NATO ally.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine merits the strongest possible military response and the toughest sanctions, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Monday, adding that the West should not be deterred by the threat of retaliation from Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Gina Heeb
title: Fatal Shooting of Deliveryman Stuns a Queens Neighborhood
description: Zhiwen Yan, who delivered Chinese food in Forest Hills, had a signature greeting for customers: “Hello, my friend!” He was killed on his scooter at a stoplight.
content: A restaurant deliveryman was shot and killed at a stoplight in Queens, the police said on Sunday, an act that has shocked and unnerved a neighborhood where he was a beloved fixture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Myra Noveck
title: Israel condemns Russian foreign minister’s comments as antisemitic.
description: Israel’s response is among the fiercest criticism it has leveled at the Russian government since the invasion of Ukraine.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli prime minister, Naftali Bennett, condemned on Monday a recent claim by the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, that Jews were “the biggest antisemites.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: An uninvited guest at the gala: talk of the new Anna Wintour biography.
description: The book, written without the Vogue editor’s direct participation, was dismissed by its subject.
content: When Anna Wintour, officially an honorary co-chair of the Met Gala, unofficially its prime mastermind, takes her customary place this evening atop the museum stairs to greet her famous guests, she will be doing so not just in the shadow of the giant, eagle-bedecked marquee, but that of a new, unauthorized biography: “Anna,” by Amy Odell. Met watchers and Met attendees alike may well be rubbing their hands in anticipatory glee, and whispering over dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: monotonous
description: This word has appeared in 48 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word monotonous has appeared in 48 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 5 in “What Daily Routine Videos Actually Show Us” by Sophie Haigney:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO Max, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in May
description: Looking for something new to watch? Here’s a roundup of the most promising titles coming to most major U.S. streaming services (except Netflix) this month.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of May’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Begins $3 Billion Plan for Electric Car Batteries
description: The Biden administration is planning a major shift to electric vehicles, but experts say it requires a secure, resilient supply of critical minerals.
content: The Biden administration plans to begin a $3.1 billion effort on Monday to spur the domestic production of advanced batteries, which are essential to its plan to speed the adoption of electric vehicles and renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 2, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 2, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Cooking Delicious Vegetarian Food: A Virtual Event
description: The chef and writer Samin Nosrat will speak with The Times’s Tejal Rao and Emily Weinstein, who will also offer guidance on readers’ vegetarian home cooking challenges.
content: Do you find yourself drawn to spring produce as the days get longer? Are you trying to eat less meat for environmental reasons? Or are you simply interested in making the tastiest possible vegetarian food at home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: A U.S. diplomat says Russia is planning to annex parts of Ukraine with ‘sham’ elections.
description: The official said that Russia may also try to take over parts of Ukraine by imposing “puppets and proxies” in local governments and forcing out democratically elected officials.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia appears to be preparing to annex two regions in eastern Ukraine and possibly a third in the country’s south, a senior American diplomat said on Monday, citing “highly credible” reports of Moscow’s plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Gorsuch Calls for Overruling ‘Shameful’ Cases on U.S. Territories
description: The justice urged his colleagues to revisit the Insular Cases, which denied full constitutional protection to unincorporated territories. A petition filed last week gives them a chance.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Neil M. Gorsuch last month issued a 10-page concurring opinion that amounted to a plea. The Supreme Court, he wrote, must find a case in which to overrule a series of discredited decisions issued in the early 1900s that were based on racist assumptions and imperial ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Oscar Isaac Learned to Love Blockbusters Again in ‘Moon Knight’
description: He wasn’t necessarily looking for another “Star Wars” or “X-Men” experience, but Isaac, the versatile screen heartthrob, has found satisfaction with this unconventional Marvel superhero.
content: At this point in its history, Marvel isn’t known for tinkering with its proven superhero formula. And yet “Moon Knight,” the studio’s current Disney+ series, has taken some unexpected chances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Maxmin and Canyon Woodward
title: What Democrats Don’t Understand About Rural America
description: The only way for the party to regain traction in rural places is by running strong campaigns in districts that usually back Republicans.
content: NOBLEBORO, Maine — We say this with love to our fellow Democrats: Over the past decade, you willfully abandoned rural communities. As the party turned its focus to the cities and suburbs, its outreach became out of touch and impersonal. To rural voters, the message was clear: You don’t matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Teacher Suspended for Telling Students to Pick Cotton in Slavery Lesson
description: Parents at a school in Rochester, N.Y., said Patrick Rausch, a white social studies teacher, had also instructed his seventh-grade students to call him “massah.”
content: A teacher in Rochester, N.Y., was placed on leave and is being investigated after parents said he told students to pick cotton during a lesson on slavery, school district officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Enters Higher Coronavirus Risk Level as Case Numbers Rise
description: The city moved into the medium risk level, known as yellow, as it sees a troubling increase in cases and the mayor weighs bringing back some restrictions.
content: New York City entered a higher risk level for the coronavirus on Monday, a troubling reminder that the pandemic is not over and that the virus still has the power to harm New Yorkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Olsen
title: Pucci Returns to Capri
description: Who needs a fashion show when you can have three days of parties and yoga? Inside Camille Miceli’s high-energy, up-with-prints, Instagram-friendly debut.
content: CAPRI, Italy — In a location that requires no filter, it was astonishing how many such tools were being used on a springlike April afternoon. The occasion? A fresh start for Emilio Pucci, the Florentine label founded by Marchese Emilio Pucci in 1947, and the first offerings under its new artistic director, Camille Miceli. About 175 guests were taking part in a three-day celebration of nonstop Instagram fodder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Jury to Consider Whether Trump Illegally Interfered in 2020 Election
description: The panel will have up to a year to recommend whether the prosecutor should pursue criminal charges against the former president and his allies.
content: ATLANTA — As the criminal investigation of Donald J. Trump by Manhattan prosecutors appears to be stalling out, the separate investigation into whether the former president and his allies illegally interfered with Georgia’s 2020 election results took a significant step forward on Monday, as 23 people were chosen to serve on a special investigative grand jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An International Art Fair, With a Side of Oysters
description: Roving teams of shuckers open and serve free oysters and Champagne at the European Fine Art Foundation at the Park Avenue Armory.
content: At the European Fine Art Foundation (TEFAF), an international art fair held at the Park Avenue Armory this week, oysters are included. Roving teams of shuckers open and serve oysters and Champagne, gratis, so visitors can slurp while they shop. Red Oyster, a New York company, supplies the bivalves and shuckers. The fair, based in Maastricht, the Netherlands, is returning to New York after a two-year Covid hiatus, from Thursday through May 10 (May 5 by invitation only).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Former N.Y.P.D. Officer Convicted of Assault in Jan. 6 Case
description: Thomas Webster was found guilty in federal court after assaulting a Washington, D.C., police officer with a metal flagpole during the riot at the Capitol last year.
content: A former New York City police officer who claimed he was acting in self-defense when he swung a metal flagpole at a fellow officer during the attack on the Capitol last January was convicted on Monday of all charges, including assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What to Know About the Stanley Cup Playoffs
description: Can the Lightning win a third straight championship? Will the Maple Leafs finally win a round? How far can the Rangers go? Will the Panthers’ success in the regular season continue?
content: The Tampa Bay Lightning are seeking to become the first team to win three straight Stanley Cups since the early ’80s Islanders. But 15 other teams and four rounds of playoffs stand in their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Hershovitz
title: How to Pray to a God You Don’t Believe In
description: I like my religion inscrutable.
content: The world is awful at the moment. Millions have died of Covid-19. Authoritarianism is on the rise, abroad and at home. And now there’s war, with all the death, destruction and dislocation that entails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: How to Stop Speeding Drivers? Scare Them.
description: Traffic deaths in New York City have risen to the highest level in eight years. A new campaign aims to shock them into slowing down.
content: A new billboard in East New York shows a pedestrian thrown into the air after bouncing off the front of a car, as his coffee splashes everywhere. “Speeding ruins lives,” it says. “Slow down.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Figure Skating Federation Proposes Raising Minimum Age to Compete
description: A medical assessment by the International Skating Union said that elite competition may hurt younger athletes in terms of their “psychological and social development.”
content: How young is too young in the crucible of elite, international sports?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson
title: Painful Stories Emerge From Mariupol, While Combat Rages to the East
description: With its forces making only slow progress and enduring heavy losses, Russia now plans to annex eastern parts of Ukraine after a sham election, the U.S. says.
content: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — Ukrainian civilians evacuated from the ruined city of Mariupol carried with them fresh accounts of survival and terror on Monday as Western nations worked to turn their increasingly expansive promises of aid into action, preparing billions of dollars in military and economic assistance, an oil embargo and other once-unthinkable steps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Kathy Boudin, Radical Imprisoned in a Fatal Robbery, Dies at 78
description: She had a role in the Brink’s heist by the Weather Underground that left two police officers dead. But she became a model prisoner and, after being freed, helped former inmates.
content: Kathy Boudin, who as a member of the radical Weather Underground of the 1960s and ’70s took part in the murderous 1981 holdup of a Brink’s armored truck and then, in prison and after being freed two decades later, helped inmates struggling to get their lives on track, died on Sunday in New York. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Secret Sounds of “Dune”: Rice Krispies and Marianne Faithfull’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the great lengths the creators of the film went to record its sounds, then act as sound designers and create their own original noises.
content: Featured Article: “The Secret Sounds of ‘Dune’: Rice Krispies and Marianne Faithfull” by Kyle Buchanan, Photographs by Peter Fisher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Spirit Airlines rejects JetBlue’s acquisition offer.
description: The airline said regulators would be skeptical of letting the companies merge as long as JetBlue was in a partnership with American Airlines.
content: Spirit Airlines on Monday rebuffed an acquisition offer from JetBlue Airways, saying regulators were unlikely to approve the proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Joe Campanale’s New Book Explores ‘Real Italian Wine’
description: The sommelier and restaurateur takes you through Italy’s 20 regions, focusing on native grapes and artisan producers.
content: The sommelier and restaurateur Joe Campanale’s new wine book, “Vino: The Essential Guide to Real Italian Wine,” is not for novices. But those who already understand Chianti and the D.O.C.G. classification might be primed to discover wines made by small producers from native grapes like frappato, grechetto and bonarda. Mr. Campanale started in the wine business in his early 20s and received a solid education from experts like the wine educator Linda Lawry (who died in November). Here he ignores pinot grigio but delves into orange wines and whites that benefit from aging, names his favorite labels and takes you through Italy’s 20 regions, describing the terroir, grapes, history and wineries that distinguish each.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Modern Pentathlon Trades Horses for an Obstacle Course
description: Months after claims of animal abuse led the sport’s governing body to announce it would change, the verdict is in, and the equestrian event is out.
content: Since its creation more than a century ago, modern pentathlon has always required its champions to be great at five things: running, swimming, shooting, fencing and horseback riding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: As Rosters Shrink, the Mets Say Goodbye to Robinson Canó
description: A popular veteran in the clubhouse who was struggling at the plate after a yearlong suspension, Canó will be cut despite entering the season being owed $40.5 million by the Mets.
content: Roster sizes in Major League Baseball shrank Monday, and the Mets made the most notable cut, parting ways with second baseman Robinson Canó, who has struggled in the twilight of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How Ohio’s Map Will Test J.D. Vance’s Political Allure
description: Behind the wild language, the “Hillbilly Elegy” author’s bid for a Senate seat follows a traditional Republican playbook.
content: Theodore Roosevelt, a renowned political animal and polymath, once said, “I think there is only one thing in the world I can’t understand, and that is Ohio politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Beach Dunes Eats & Arts Café in Queens Provides Affordable Food
description: The cafe and farmers’ market offers prepared items, produce and pantry staples in an affordable housing unit near Far Rockaway.
content: A cafe and market has opened at Beach Green Dunes II, an affordable housing development in Edgemere, Queens, near Far Rockaway. With a mission to provide modestly priced food to the neighborhood, the cafe sells whole roast chickens and prepared items, $4 to $21, for delivery, to eat in or take away. There is a daily $5 lunch special, and EBT is accepted. Produce and pantry items are available at the farmers’ market on the premises, from the Campaign Against Hunger’s Far Rock Farm; there is also a kitchen for cooking classes and job training in food. It’s open to all, Tuesday through Friday, 7 a.m. to 3 p.m.; and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: A Ballerina Harnesses Her Wild Imagination to Choreography
description: “There are no rules,” says Janie Taylor, a former City Ballet principal, whose dances are featured in the L.A. Dance Project’s Joyce Theater season.
content: When Benjamin Millepied suggested three years ago that Janie Taylor try her hand at choreography for his company, the L.A. Dance Project, she had an immediate response: “That’s crazy,” she told him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Putin’s Failure to Hold on to the Educated Could Be the World’s Gain
description: Russians who oppose the war enough to leave should be welcomed as a boon to productivity.
content: Since Russia’s war on Ukraine began, press reports have focused on the exodus from Russia of antiwar scientists, engineers and information technology experts. But the vast majority of the Russian people are staying put, and actually rallying behind President Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: The Federal Reserve’s Tough Spot
description: A stock market dive complicates the fight against inflation.
content: The Federal Reserve is meeting this week. The economy is running hot, and the Fed is trying to slow it down before widespread price pressures become even more of a problem. It lifted interest rates in March for the first time since 2018, by a quarter of a percentage point, and has set the stage for an even larger increase of half a percentage point this week. The announcement is expected to come at the conclusion of the Fed’s two-day policy meeting on Wednesday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Outdoor Planters
description: Spring is here (whether or not it feels like it), and it’s time to spruce up the patio.
content: Outdoor planters can transform almost any hard surface — a terrace, a balcony, even a stoop — into a garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Draymond Green Leaves Early, but Golden State Shows Tenacity Late
description: Jordan Poole came off the bench to score 31 points as Golden State overcame Green’s first-half ejection.
content: MEMPHIS — Moments before they learned Draymond Green had been ejected from the game, Golden State Warriors Coach Steve Kerr and guard Stephen Curry looked out at the crowd Green had enraged. Kerr and Curry laughed as fans chanted, “Throw him out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in May
description: Here are the most promising new and returning titles for U.S. subscribers this month, including a new season of “Stranger Things.”
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of May’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Who Should Be the Next Mayor of Los Angeles?
description: The primary election will be held on June 7.
content: In a little over a month, voters will decide who should run Los Angeles, America’s second-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Johnny Depp Lost $22.5 Million ‘Pirates’ Role After Op-Ed, Manager Says
description: Mr. Depp’s talent manager said the actor had been up to play Captain Jack Sparrow again until his ex-wife, Amber Heard, wrote an op-ed saying she was a “public figure representing domestic abuse.”
content: Johnny Depp’s talent manager testified on Monday in the actor’s defamation trial that Mr. Depp lost a $22.5 million deal to star in a sixth “Pirates of the Caribbean” movie after his ex-wife, Amber Heard, published an op-ed in which she called herself a “public figure representing domestic abuse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Abbott
title: Welcome to ‘Single White Female’ With a Maternal Twist
description: In Elizabeth Day’s psychological thriller, “Magpie,” an obsessive, boundary-pushing lodger upends the lives of a picture-perfect couple trying to have a baby.
content: “What is she going to do?” wonders Marisa, the nervous, eager-to-conceive woman in “Magpie,” Elizabeth Day’s fourth novel. “In a cheap film — the kind that she watches on cable channels in the afternoons lying on the sofa when she should be working — the wronged woman would pack her bags and leave the house in a fit of righteous indignation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Plan to Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda Stokes Anger and Dread
description: The government’s proposal has led to recriminations from rights groups, and anxiety among migrants who fear being sent away.
content: FOLKESTONE, England — Nearly every day, Kamal Mohamad calls home to his parents in Iraq from the converted military barracks on the outskirts of Folkestone, a coastal town in Kent, southeastern England, where he is awaiting a decision on his asylum claim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia tries to gain ground in Ukraine’s east.
content: Nancy Pelosi, the U.S. House speaker, met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv over the weekend. Her visit signaled a deepening U.S. commitment to Ukraine: Pelosi is the most senior American official to visit the country since the war began, and she pledged U.S. support “until victory is won.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: ‘We Were Liars’ Was a Y.A. Sensation. But How Is the New Prequel?
description: Eight years after her Y.A. psychological thriller “We Were Liars,” E. Lockhart returns with a prequel, “Family of Liars.”
content: Sometimes a book is a book and sometimes a book is a phenomenon. E. Lockhart’s 2014 Y.A. psychological thriller “We Were Liars” is, without a doubt, a phenomenon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spain Says Cellphones of Prime Minister and Defense Minister Were Hacked
description: Officials said the devices were breached by the Pegasus spyware, made by an Israeli company, which is intended to track illegal behavior but has been misused by some governments.
content: MADRID — Data was downloaded from cellphones used by the prime minister and the defense minister of Spain that were infected with powerful spyware known as Pegasus from an Israeli company, the country’s government said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Amy Qin
title: Beijing reopens a mass isolation center and tries to avoid a citywide lockdown.
description: While the Chinese capital has recorded only a few hundred cases in recent weeks, the move to reopen the facility appears to be aimed at avoiding the fate of Shanghai.
content: The authorities in Beijing on Monday said that they had reopened a mass coronavirus isolation center, the latest in a raft of measures to try to stave off a citywide lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline de Gruyter
title: Europe Is in Danger. It Always Is.
description: In a world of war and calamity, the European Union needs to pull together even more.
content: BRUSSELS — In July 2020, along with European officials and experts, I was asked to take part in a policy game. Convened by a German think tank, we were asked to play out what would happen if either Matteo Salvini or Marine Le Pen, the far-right leaders in Italy and France, came to power. We spent a few hours frenziedly debating how the European Union would respond to each occurrence. Of one thing we were sure: It would be a disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: Democrats argued in a 17-page complaint that there simply was not enough time to implement the order from the State Court of Appeals for new district lines.
content: Democrats argued in a 17-page complaint that there simply was not enough time to implement the order from the State Court of Appeals for new district lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Why Critics of Angry Woke College Kids Are Missing the Point
description: “If we just focus on this generation’s political style,” says political theorist Wendy Brown, “we ignore their rage at the world they’ve inherited.”
content: “If we just focus on this generation’s political style,” says political theorist Wendy Brown, “we ignore their rage at the world they’ve inherited.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Chad?
description: Can you find Chad on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 16 million people?
content: Can you find Chad on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 16 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $5 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Santa Monica, a 1925 Tudor Revival home in Ojai and a Craftsman-inspired bungalow in Los Gatos.
content: A Spanish-style house in Santa Monica, a 1925 Tudor Revival home in Ojai and a Craftsman-inspired bungalow in Los Gatos.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Met Gala 2022 Photos: Gilded Glamour on the Red Carpet
description: Celebrities took their best swing at an ambiguous dress code.
content: Celebrities took their best swing at an ambiguous dress code.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Ukrainians Fleeing Fighting in the East Arrive in Zaporizhzhia
description: Civilians displaced from the Russian-occupied city of Mariupol and other areas of eastern Ukraine crossed the frontline into Zaporizhzhia in the country’s southeast.
content: Civilians displaced from the Russian-occupied city of Mariupol and other areas of eastern Ukraine crossed the frontline into Zaporizhzhia in the country’s southeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: J. Kenji López-Alt did a deep dive into one of America’s greatest sandwiches: the tuna crunch.
content: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt did some solid shoe-leather reporting for The Times last week, exploring the origins of one of America’s greatest sandwiches: the tuna crunch (above).
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Florida, Social-Emotional Learning + Math = Rejection
description: Readers discuss the Florida Department of Education’s objections to some of the topics in math textbooks. Also: The Ukraine war; mask mandates.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
